text:
SPEAKER: Just to give
you a brief introduction so you know who Chelsea
is, if you don't know her. But there's so much
more that can be said,

and I will tell you and
it's one short paragraph. She's the assistant
professor of computer science

and electrical engineering
at Stanford University, and her lab is
called IRIS, so you

will see a little bit
of logo of an IRIS. And she studies intelligence
through robotic interaction

at scale, and it's a very
actually fascinating field of research she will be
telling you more about today.

So thank you again for joining. She also spends time at Google
as part of the Google Brain team. And yeah, it's my big pleasure
that she's able to join us.

She's also going to teach
two classes actually just in a couple of weeks, and
you can find more information

on the platform. One of them is graduate class
CS224R Deep Reinforcement

Learning, which
starts on April 2. And the other one is a
professional class CS330 Deep

Multi-Task and Meta
Learning, and it starts only, I think, next Monday,
so it's very, very soon.

So yeah, she's a wonderful
instructor, wonderful person to have here. So thank you so much
once again for joining.

CHELSEA FINN: Really
happy to be here and excited about to
share some of our research on deep learning for
robotics and specifically

talk about where
the frontier is. I'm also seeing some
questions in the Q&A about there being a recording. And yes, this will be
recorded, and the recording

will be posted online. Great. So to get started, I think
a great place to start

is to think about, what
can robots do today? And we've seen
examples of robots

being able to complete fairly
complex manipulation tasks, like being able to use a spatula
to lift an object into a bowl,

or really impressive videos
from Boston Dynamics that allow robots to do really
impressive maneuvers,

such as parkour-like maneuvers
in environments like this.

And the catch with these
kinds of impressive behaviors is that, first in terms of
the Boston Dynamics behavior,

it's really
undoubtedly impressive. But the behavior was
manually tuned for this one particular environment.

And the manipulation
task of using the spatula to lift an object was
trained using 15 minutes

of data in that environment. And as a result,
these behaviors are

specialized to the environments
that they were trained in and the environments that
the behavior was tuned for.

And this means that they're
learning very narrow behaviors, that robots are able to
perform complex maneuvers

in narrow and
controlled environments. And if you move one of
these different platforms

a little bit, or if you gave
the robot a different spatula, the behavior would
ultimately fail.

And so what I'm
really interested in is how we might allow
robots to actually go

out into the real world,
in real environments, like homes, offices,
and so forth, and actually allow
them to generalize,

to perform intelligent
behavior in those settings. Now, the tricky part
is that we often

train robots on a fairly
narrow distribution, such as in a lab environment.

And our goal is to be able
to actually deploy robots into the real world.

And from the standpoint
of machine learning, this means that actually
generalizing to this wider distribution is
pretty challenging

because it was trained on a
fairly narrow distribution with the small number of
objects and a small number

of environments. And so I think that there's
two possible solutions.

And I think that both of these
solutions are really important. The first is to train on a
larger and broader data set.

Try to think if we
can scale the data that we're training
robots on so that they can generalize fairly broadly.

And arguably, this
training neural networks on larger data sets is one
of the only recipes that's convincingly enabled in
the wild generalization

in other domains, like
speech recognition, machine translation, and
image classification.

And I think that
this sort of thing will be really important
and necessary to get robots to generalize.

But I think that actually doing
this won't quite be sufficient, because I think that robots will
inevitably encounter scenarios

that are a little bit
different than the scenarios that they are trained on simply
because the world is vast

and has lots of
different scenarios and lots of different
environments and objects, and so forth.

And so the second
ingredient that I think is really
important is to think about how robots might
also be able to generalize

beyond the data that
they were trained on. And I don't think we
can hope to anticipate

every possible scenario, so
what we're going to look at is thinking about whether we
can allow the robots to adapt

at test time also. And if they're able to take
in a tiny amount of experience at test time and adapt and
learn from that experience,

then they might be
able to actually handle novel situations. So these two things,
training on broader data sets

and generalizing beyond
the training distribution, are the two main
things that I'll talk about in this webinar.

And of course, this
will only really be scratching the
surface of this broader topic of deep
learning for robotics

but should give you a
pretty good sense for where the field is at today.

Great. So first, let's think about
whether we can train robots across many different
tasks, and the specific goal

that we're going to focus
on is to allow a robot to generalize to a new task
that it wasn't specifically

trained to do. And we're hoping to be able to
do this by actually broadening the training data distribution.

It's worth mentioning that
there are some previous research efforts that have tried to aim
to allow robots to generalize

to new tasks by, for
example, enabling robots to generalize to new objects--

but this was all
trained and tested within the single
skill of placing-- or being able to generalize
to new instructions,

like new language instructions. But the new instructions
will describe behaviors seen in the data.

What we'd like to
do is we'd like to take this a little bit
further and be looking at allowing robots
to generalize two

different combinations
of objects across a wide range of skills.

So in terms of evaluating
whether a robot can do a new task, we'll
consider an example.

So say the robot
is in this scene, and we want to be able to
tell the robot to place

the grapes in the ceramic bowl. The robot in this case--
the data we'll have seen

will be showing it how
to place other objects into the ceramic
bowl and how to do

other things with the grapes,
but it won't have ever seen a behavior that picks
up grapes and puts it into the ceramic bowl,
all in one trajectory.

And to make things a little
bit harder than that, we're actually only
going to show it data from two different object sets.

And it won't have
ever seen any data of the grapes and this ceramic
bowl in the same scene.

Great. So then we're going to train on
a hundred total sets of tasks, where a task corresponds
to a specific behavior

or trajectory. And these tasks
are going to cover nine different underlying
skills, including

things like grasping, placing,
pushing, wiping, and so forth. And an example of these
kinds of behaviors

is shown in this
video, where you can see examples such as
placing the banana in the tray,

dragging the ceramic bowl
in a circle, and so forth.

Great. So this is an example
of the behavior that we're showing the robot,
and this data was collected

by using a VR controller to
move the gripper of the robot in a particular way.

And this is an example
of 12 different tasks, but we're going to
show a data of around a hundred different tasks.

And then, once we collect
this data showing a hundred different tasks,
we're then going to train a neural
network policy that

will take as input an
RGB image and output a desired target position and
orientation of the gripper.

And so this policy
will be outputting seven numbers, 3 numbers
for the position, 3 for the orientation, as
well as one number that

corresponds to the opening
and closing of the gripper. This policy will
operate at 10 hertz

such that it takes in a new
image 10 times every second and predicts a new action.

We chose this representation
because it's maximally general. This sort of policy
in principle could do lots of different
tasks, depending

on the data that you trade on. And importantly,
this policy is also going to be conditioned on
a description of the task.

And we're specifically going
to use language descriptions, and we'll use a fixed
pretrained language model

to get embeddings of
these instructions and then pass those
embeddings into the policy.

Great. So once we've trained this
policy on our diverse data set, in order for the robot to
generalize to a new task,

identify relevant
objects and distractors; and lastly, translate
it's interpretation

of the instruction and what it
sees into the robot's action space. And doing this all for a novel
task is quite challenging.

And as we'll see,
we are actually able to get some degree
of generalization.

So for example, if we
go back to the scenario that we looked at before,
where the goal was to place

the grape in the ceramic bowl. We gave it exactly that
language instruction, and this is, again,
a task trajectory

that it never saw in the data. And the robot is able to
successfully complete the task.

Similarly, and the thing
that's really great is that the robot isn't able
to just perform one task

but is actually able to perform
a number of different tasks that it didn't see
in the training

set, such as placing the banana
on the white sponge placing a bottle in the tray and pushing
a purple bowl across the table.

Great. So now let's look at
some of the actually

quantitative experiments
that actually evaluate the success of the policy. And in particular,
we preselected

a set of 28 tasks
that are held out from all of the
training data, and then

we evaluated performance. And I emphasize
"preselected" in the sense that we didn't just pick the
task that the robot worked on.

We preselected a number of
tasks that are all held out. All of these tasks are shown
in this big table right here.

And we see that first the
robot has a non-zero success rate for 20 out of 28
of the held-out tasks.

The average success
rate is around 32% over all of the 28 tasks. And so overall,
this suggests first

that there is really substantial
signs of the robot being able to do tasks that it never
saw any training data for,

which is really exciting. But second, there's
also considerable room for improvement and actually
boosting this number from 32%

upward. And then you can ask, where
is the room for improvement in terms of the robot's
ability to do these tasks?

And so to understand where
the room for improvement is, we evaluated the
robot's performance

on the training tasks, with
either just a one hot ID for the task, as well as
a language instruction

for the task. And then we also
evaluated, of course, this 32% number, which is
held-out tasks with language

conditioning. And first, we see
that if we actually evaluate the robot
on training tasks,

on tasks that it
was trained to do, the performance is
actually only 40%. There's only an 8% gap in being
able to actually generalize

to a new task. And the really larger gap
is actually bringing up

this 42% number up
to 100%, and this means that, really,
the bottleneck is just

the robot's ability to complete
the tasks in the first place. And we can actually look at
example failure cases of--

example failure cases
of what the robot does for tasks that it
has a 0% success rate for.

And I'm not sure if
these videos are playing, but what these videos show is
that, even though this policy

has a 0% success rate, the
robot is actually really close to completing the task.

So for the "Place banana
in the ceramic cup," it actually knows to
pick up the banana and move it towards the
cup, but doesn't quite

complete the last
stage of the task. And for the second
task of wiping the tray with the sponge,
it also figures out

that it should
pick up the sponge and tries to move
towards the tray. But it isn't able
to complete the very

last stage of the task. And so this suggests that
first the 0% success metric

is quite strict, and it
also suggests that we just-- just, the ability to
control the robot arm

is the major bottleneck in
terms of completing these tasks.

Great. So that was a proof of
concept that we can actually

allow robots to generalize
to new tasks which is-- to start to generalize
to new tasks, which is pretty exciting.

Now there's a question of,
what if we scale up even more? So we are previously looking
at around a hundred tasks.

The next step is we tried
actually scaling this to more than 700 tasks
using 130,000 trajectories

or demonstrations
of those tasks. We found that if we took the
model from the previous work

that I mentioned and just
tried to make it larger, that didn't actually
necessarily improve performance. It seems like this kind
of model architecture

isn't able to
actually absorb all of the information in
this larger data set.

And so what we did is once
we scaled up this data set, we tried to actually see if we
could design an architecture

that is better at capturing-- better at capturing all of the
kind of detailed information

in this larger data set. And so, specifically
we designed what we're referring to as
a robotics transformer.

Similar to before,
this is going to be taking an input images
and an instruction and outputting an action.

But there's a number
of important components that allow this
architecture to be better at absorbing lots of data.

The first is that
we're going to tokenize the inputs and the outputs
into discrete tokens.

We're going to use a transformer
as part of this architecture, and transformers
have been widely used

in natural language processing. And we find that
they're actually a very effective
architecture here as well for being able to leverage
large amounts of data.

And because our actions are
now discretized with tokens, we'll use a cross-entropy
style objective.

And then, for reading
as input the images, we'll use a convolutional
neural network

called an effecient
net, as well as a film architecture to
condition on the instruction. This backbone of the
network will be pretrained,

and then the output of
these image and embeddings will be tokenized
with a token learner.

I don't want to get into too
much of the details here, but the biggest part
here is that we're able to actually train this
on a really large data set,

on a 130,000 episodes. This data set was
collected across 13 robots over 17 months, covering
more than 700 tasks.

And what we found is when
we actually evaluated this model on both scene
tasks, as well as tasks that

were unseen,
distractors that were new, and different
background scenes,

this model architecture
shown in blue was able to substantially
outperform previous model

architectures, including
the architecture that we used in
the previous work, as well as the Gato
style architecture,

which is an architecture
developed by DeepMind.

Great. So the takeaway here is that
if we scale up robotics data

and train these big policies
on these broad data sets, that allows robots to
start to generalize

in lots of different
ways, including to new tasks, new distractor
objects in the scene,

and new backgrounds
in the scene. We've also released the
data from the first work,

and there's a link
available right here. Great.

And then the other
thing that I'd like to briefly touch on
on this data set front

is this bigger
level picture, which is that, typically in
robot learning research,

the way that most research
progresses is that first we will collect a data
set for a project,

then complete that
project with that data set, and then don't
use that data again for the next project.

For the next project,
we'll collect the new data set for that project. And as you might imagine,
this is really inefficient.

And if you contrast this to
what typical machine learning research does
outside of robotics,

typically one data
set is collected once, like ImageNet or Wikitext. And it's reused many, many
times by many different research

projects. Or even better, instead
of reusing the data set, we might re-use a model that
was pretrained on that data set

and fine tune that model or
use embeddings from that model.

And so I think it's really
important for the robot learning research
as a whole to move

towards the second paradigm and
try to move towards a scenario where we're sharing
data and pretrained

models across institutions
and, of course, across projects as well.

If we were able to share
data and pretrained

models in robotics, then
I think we could probably make a lot more progress on
the really challenging research

problems that come up here. And for example, if you
imagine what machine learning

research-- if machine learning research
did what robot learning research does and they
recollected image debt

wouldn't be where it is today. Great. So then I'll also
briefly comment on,

what's actually stopping
us from sharing data across institutions right now?

I think we have a little
bit of a challenge in that-- I'll make an analogy,
which is that I think that,

right now, what the robot
data landscape looks like is all these different
islands in this giant ocean,

where we have these
different robot data sets that have been collected. And each of them is
kind of an island that

covers the whole space of
possible robot configurations, environments,
objects, and so forth.

And because these data
sets are not super diverse and because the whole possible
space of robotics hardware

and environments and
so forth is so broad, this means that, when another
research project is going

to try out a task and try out
studying a particular problem,

that research project usually
ends up somewhere over here or over here. And this means
that the data sets

that have been collected before
aren't useful for actually advancing that new robotics
experiment or that new task,

or problem, or environment. And so one of the
efforts that we're trying to do right now is to try
to see first if we can collect

data from many, many
distinct environments, not just from one
building, and also trying

to see if we can have
a more centralized community-driven data collection
effort that may allow us to unify some of
the design choices

so that, first, we can have
a larger island, and second, we can bring more people
towards a single island

by actually having everyone
agree upon certain design choices. And so our goal
is to collect data

from lots of different real
household environments. Our initial goal was around
50 different households,

but we actually
think that we might be able to significantly
expand that with the interest that we've seen so far.

And we've been developing a-- integrating people from lots
of different universities to try to contribute
to this effort.

And of course, if you're
interested in contributing, feel free to reach out.

Cool, so the first
part of this talk, I talked about trying to train
robots on broader data sets.

And we saw that we can get signs
of zero-shot generalization to new tasks and environments.

But we should also
probably try to share data across institutions and use
data more frequently, such

that we can allow robots to
actually generalize further and generalize to the
extent that we see things

outside of robotics
generalizing well. Great. So now I'd like to
also briefly talk

about how robots might
generalize beyond the training distribution. And we'll first look
at this in the context

of a simple grasping
problem, where the training environment and
the grasping policy

was initially trained in
this sort of environment. It's a bin. Its goal is to pick
objects from this bin.

And we're going to
then try to test the policy in a number of
different environments,

and we're actually
specifically going to pick environments that we
found that the policy worked poorly in. This includes with harsh
lighting conditions,

with transparent objects that
it didn't see during training, with the checkerboard
background, as well as a physical
change where we actually

move the gripper of the
robot by 10 centimeters. And the policy in the
training environment

was fairly successful. It had an 86% success rate. And when we actually
tried to put it

under these new conditions,
the success rate dropped significantly to
32%, 49%, 50%, and 43%.

And one of the things
I mentioned before is that it's really impossible
to anticipate and prepare

for any possible scenario that
the robot might find itself in. And so what we're
going to do is we're going to try to see
if the robot can adapt

to a small amount of
data that was collected in this new environment.

And so specifically,
what this will look like is we have our
original data set collected in the original environment.

We're going to use a
reinforcement learning algorithm called QT-Opt to
train a Q-function and a policy

for grasping in
this environment. This policy, again,
gets 86% success rate.

And then we're going
to allow the robot to collect a very small amount
of data, only 800 attempts,

which can be collected in
around a single afternoon in this new environment.

In this case, this is
the displaced gripper. And then we're going
to take our Q-function

and simply fine-tune
it on this target data by using a mixture of the
base data and the new data,

And then, with this very
simple fine-tuning procedure, which is very common in the
rest of machine learning,

we see that the policy can
get around a 98% success rate, even though this environment is
completely different from what

it saw during training.  And we did a pretty fairly
thorough quantitative

evaluation there, looking at
a variety of physical changes and visual changes. I don't want to get into
all the numbers here,

but a few highlights
is that, first, we can see a fairly strong
improvement in success rate, even after only 25 new attempts
in the new environment.

And here's actually a
video of the policy--

the policy in one of
these new environments. And so in this case, with an
afternoon's worth of data,

it's able to adapt
to this new scenario and successfully handle
the physical change
that we imposed on the robot.  Cool.

So this was all specifically
in the context of grasping, and we saw that the
robot can autonomously collect some data to
adapt to a new setting.

Now, what about in general? Can we do this for any
sort of robotics task?

Ideally, what we could do
is we could allow the robot

to autonomously collect data and
adapt with that collected data,

but there's a little
bit of a challenge here. And the challenge is
that if we collect a trajectory with
reinforcement learning,

the robot attempts the task. We collect one
trajectory, and then we collect another trajectory,
and so on and so forth.

Typically, in reinforcement
learning with the trial and error process, we assume
that the robot can attempt

the task multiple times. But one subtle point is
that it's actually unclear

if we want the robot to
autonomously adapt on its own how it will actually get to
the last state of a trajectory

back to the first date of its
next attempt to retry the task. And in a lot of
simulation environments,

you can just reset
the environment and allow it to
attempt it again.

But in the real
world, if we want robots to adapt on the fly in
their new deployed setting,

this sort of reset
isn't possible. It might require a
human to do something,

and it prevents the robot
from autonomously adapting with a small amount of data.

And so, oftentimes,
what this looks like is, for example,
if a robot is trying to hit a puck into
a goal, this robot

actually isn't physically
capable of moving the puck back. And oftentimes, a
human will reset

the puck between each trial. Or if they're robots trying
to learn how to open a door, a person will then close
the door before every trial.

And what ideally we'd
like to be able to do is to allow robots to adapt
without these kinds of resets.

Now, you might
ask, well, maybe we can just run reinforcement
learning algorithms without resets, just run
the same exact algorithms

that we use when they do
get these kinds of resets, and maybe those are still work.

And so we tried doing that,
so we took a very simple environment where the
goal is, in simulation,

to have this fish move
to a certain goal. And it turns out
that if you give it

a reset every thousand steps,
it learns a performance policy at the task.

But if you give it a reset
only every 2,000 steps, it isn't able to get
as high of performance

over the course of learning. And if you give it a reset
even less frequently,

the robot hardly
is able to learn a policy for the task at all.

And so perhaps
surprisingly, algorithms for reinforcement
learning aren't well-designed for
this scenario, where

the robot is
operating completely autonomously on its own. And this means that
if we want to use these algorithms to
allow robots to adapt

during deployment at test
time in the real world, they aren't going to be
well-suited for that.

And so this motivated
us to introduce this problem of single-life
reinforcement learning

and, in contrast to episodic
reinforcement learning, where you can try things
again and again or reset-free reinforcement
learning, where

you can try to both
learn how to do the task and undo the task, what
we're going to look at

is a scenario where we have
some previous experience. And so the robot has possibly
used these previous experiences

to learn a good policy. Then the agent is faced with a
new environment at test time,

and its goal is to
basically complete the task fully autonomously
within a single episode

without any human resets in that
new environment at test time.

And so more succinctly,
given previous data in a training environment. The robot or the
agent has one life

to autonomously complete the
task in a novel scenario.

We'll be starting to
look at this in a very simple simulated environment. Well, I'll show some examples in
this half-cheetah environment,

where, for example,
during training, it just needs to run forward. And at test time,
it sees a scenario

that's completely
different from anything it saw during training. Specifically, there'll
be an obstacle that makes it harder to
make forward progress.
Great.

And so then our
goal will actually be to allow the robot
to actually figure out how to adapt at test time
within a single episode.

Cool. So how do we go about
approaching this problem? So first, what we
did is we actually

tried to run the robot
in this environment, and its goal is to
get to the green box.

And it was trained
in an environment without any obstacles at all. And what we're
doing here is we're

running the robot in the
simulated environment. And we're fine-tuning it
with reinforcement learning

to try to have it
update its policy and ultimately get
to the green block.

And ideally, what we
see here is it actually gets a little stuck. It gets knocked
upside down, and it

struggles to make forward
progress and get back up-- first figure out
how to get back up, and then figure out how
to get over the obstacle

to get to the goal.  And so really,
the core challenge

of this single-life
reinforcement learning problem is to handle this
sort of novelty and recover from these
out-of-distribution states,

such as being
knocked upside down, without any human intervention.

In standard reinforcement
learning algorithms that run fine-tuning
in this environment, we'll won't encourage
the agent to recover

from out-of-distribution states. Now, what we're
going to do is we're going to first
encourage the agent

to move towards the
distribution of prior data because this should help it
figure out that, when it's

knocked back over, it should try
to get back up, because that's a state that it saw
in its previous data.

But we don't want
to exactly do that. These kinds of previous
methods usually assume expert
demonstrations, and they

aim to match the entire
distribution of prior data. And instead, what
we're going to do

is we're going to have it
try to match the prior data but do so in a way that's
weighted by the estimated

value of those states. And the Q-function or
the Q-value function

will estimate the
desirability of the state. We can pretrain our Q-function
on the previous data

and then try to match
the prior data weighted by the exponentiated Q-value
of those experiences.

And this will drive
it towards states that had good outcomes
in the previous data,

and we actually tried to
run this on the same example that I mentioned before. And what we see here is
that the robot is, again,

trying to get over the hurdles. And ideally, what it would
do is it would figure out

how to get to the goal on its
own, and we see exactly that. So it does actually flip over
on its back at one point.

But most importantly,
it actually is able to figure out how
to get back up on its feet, and also figure out how
to get over the hurdles

and ultimately reach the goal. We also quantitatively evaluated
this on not just the scenario

that I showed you, but
also a few other scenarios. And we found that in
comparison to fine-tuning

with reinforcement learning,
this approach shown in yellow was more successful at
completing the task at test

time and was able to do so
in a smaller number of steps compared to fine-tuning
with reinforcement learning.

There's also a lot of
room for improvement. So I think that the sort of
problem setting that we're introducing for the
first time can actually

can be studied much
further and actually allow, hopefully
in the long run, robots to be able to
adapt to New environments
and handle novel states.

Great. So to summarize
the second part, I think it's important to
allow robots to generalize

to new scenarios
that they didn't see during training
by actually having them try to problem solve
and learn test time.

And we saw some initial
evidence that we might be able to do that
by encouraging the robot to move towards previous
data that it saw in the past.

But of course, there's
also lots of, I think, important research to be done
before actually this being

a viable solution
in the long term. And we're actively working
on trying to deploy this onto real robots so that robots
can try to adopt that test time

rather than deploying
a static policy.  Cool.

So yeah, overall,
I talked about how we might allow
robots to generalize broadly by training
on a broader data

set, and also allowing robots
to adapt beyond the training distribution.

The last thing I'd like to
touch on beyond generalization is that I also think
it's important to allow

robots to perform very
complex and dexterous tasks. So we really focus a lot on
generalization in this talk.

But ideally, robots
wouldn't just be doing very simple tasks,
like the very simple locomotion

problem that I
showed you, grasping and pick-and-place tasks. Ideally, we could
also allow robots

to do more complex tasks, like
folding laundry or tasks that

require fairly delicate
maneuvers, like peeling a hard boiled egg, for example.

And I think, to do this-- to do this well, we need
actually a data collection set up that allows robots
to do fairly complex tasks

and ideally set up
as low cost and has an easy-to-use
teleoperation system. And so this is something that
we've actually been developing.

It's still in somewhat
of the early stages, but we developed
a low-cost system

that allows the
robot to complete fairly fine-grain
manipulation tasks,

like unwrapping
a piece of candy, like putting a cable
tie around a cable,

like zipping up a
hoodie, and so forth. And the really cool
thing about this setup

is that the total
cost of all four arms in the setup and other
parts is less than $20k.

This is less than the cost
of a single industrial arm. We're also planning to open
source both the hardware setup

as well as some
software that we've developed for this system,
and it's also a lot of fun

to play with. And I think it will
help us actually move beyond simple pick-and-place
tasks to some of the tasks

that you can see here, tasks
that require dexterity, that require very quick
motions, and so forth.

We also have some
initial results that have found that
for some of these tasks, we could actually
train the robot to complete it autonomously.

Cool. Oh, yeah, and the other
thing that I'll mention here is these robots
are quite low cost.

I actually wasn't sure
that these low-cost robots would be capable of
some of these things. And actually, the manufacturer
of these robots, Trossen

Robotics, also didn't know that
their own robots were capable of these kinds of tasks, like
putting RAM into a motherboard,

for example.  Great. With that, I'd
like to acknowledge

all the members of
our research lab, and we have plenty of
time for questions.

Thanks, everyone. SPEAKER: Great Thank
you so much, Chelsea, for an extremely
interesting presentation.

And I saw a bunch of
questions coming in. We will tried to get
to as many as we can.

But if you have some
additional questions, don't hesitate to still use the
Q&A box and ask your questions.

Chelsea, I saw a number
of people very interested in the data sets you're using
and what actually the data

set is. Like, how does it look like? CHELSEA FINN: Yeah, definitely. So in the first
part of the talk,

the data set corresponded to
teleoperated demonstrations. And what that means is that
we control the robot with a VR

controller to try to match-- we program to match the
end effector of the robot

to the position of-- or basically, take actions
mimicking the position

of the VR controller. And during that process,
we record images from the robot's cameras.

We record the
position of the arm, which is measured by
the joint angles of--

the angles of all the
joints, as well as you can compute the 3D position
and orientation of the gripper.

And then we also
record the action that was commanded
to move the robot. And so generally, you can think
of this as videos plus some--

a sequence of
low-dimensional sensor measurements on the robot arm.

And then, in the
second part of the talk and some of the other stuff,
it's all very similar. So we typically use RGB images
as the observation space

of the robot. And some of the work
where I was showing that very simple simulated
running task, that

was all low dimensional. It was just looking at the
positions of all of the joints, and so forth.

But in everything else, we're
using image observations. It's also possible
to use depth, to use

tactile sensors, and so forth. There are various upsides and
downsides of different sensors,

but we've found
RGB sensors to be-- RGB cameras, like webcams, to
be a really simple and scalable

solution. SPEAKER: There is actually
a follow-up question about the image processing
or during the training

and experimentation, and you
mentioned that all of these have advantages, disadvantages. So what is the advantage
and disadvantage

of the image processing? And how can we improve it? CHELSEA FINN: Yeah, so
in all of this work,

we're basically training
neural networks end-to-end. So we're training a
single neural network to take and input the
image and output actions,

and so this means that there
isn't any computer vision pipeline that is trying to
find objects in the image,

for example. We're actually just actually
supervising the visual backbone

of the model for the
task that the robot is trying to complete. And one advantage
of this is that it

means that the
robot's perception is optimized for the task.

And the reason why this
is actually quite nice is that if you imagine
a task of, for example,

manipulating a water bottle, if
you tried to develop a vision pipeline for that, you might try
to exactly represent the three

depots of the bottle
and exactly represent the shape of the bottle. And inevitably, a vision
system will have some failures.

It won't be able to precisely
estimate all of that. And you don't actually need
all of that information

in order to do very simple
tasks, like picking up the bottle. You don't need to precisely
know the three positions.

And by optimizing the perception
pipeline for the task, it can basically learn
heuristics and learn shortcuts

and only represent the
perceptual information that it needs for the task.

SPEAKER: You
mentioned a little bit about sharing data and
data being available.

There was a
follow-up question on that about envisioning
reusing data across projects, and also institutions.

What's your take on that? And could you kindly
dive a little bit deeper on what you have
said in the presentation?

CHELSEA FINN: Yeah, definitely. So I think that it's really
critical to start actually having a shared data and
pretrained models ideally

as well. My dream is to actually
basically, at least in the short-term, be
able to develop models

like analogous to BERT or
analogous to GPT-style models that people can use off the
shelf on a robot, of course,

not for text
generation, but actually for representing actions and
representing images and so forth in a robotics
pipeline and getting value

from those kinds of models. So I think it's really important
for the community to do that.

There's also challenges. One challenge is that
the different people use different control
stocks and different robots.

Our initial efforts is we are-- at least with the
community-driven effort that I mentioned, we're
trying to at least start

with a single robot
platform and set up but then diversify in terms of
environments, objects, tasks,

and so forth. And that can at least give us
a little bit of a certainty in terms of trying to--

it's a little bit less risky in
that we can focus on a platform that a lot of people
in the community use. And then, in the long-term,
I think it's really important

to also start to develop
pretrained models that are

a little bit more agnostic
to the particular hardware so that-- maybe you can't zero-shot
handle a new robot,

but you might be able
to spin up a new robot platform more quickly
than if you were

to do everything from scratch. Yeah, so I think that those
are some of the considerations.

SPEAKER: Perfect. Thank you so much. When you show the last
video like with the egg

and ripping the candy and
all these kind of thing, there was a lot of
excitement, actually,

in the audience about that. And the follow-up question or
one of the follow-up questions is about, how far are we
in getting this further

or making this actually
the standard thing happening in the world, like,
making it even applicable

and using it in practice? CHELSEA FINN: Yeah,
so we're really excited about that project
too, and it's something

that we're actively working on. We're actually going
to be releasing a paper around that work
probably one week from today,

certainly definitely
within the next two weeks. And our initial progress
on that is actually

we've been able to train
neural networks to do some kinds of tasks
like that, specifically a task like slotting a
battery into a remote control,

like being able to tear
off a piece of tape and put it on a box,
and things like that,

put a shoe on a person. But there's also
lots of challenges. So I guess, well, first,
we are-- like I mentioned,

we're open-sourcing
the hardware setup, and so we're hoping
that other people will be as excited about the
platform as we are and actually

develop it and/or buy it
themselves and collect data on it, and so forth.

There are other
challenges associated with getting policies to do
those kinds of tasks as well.

One challenge that
we've run into is that we've been able to do
some tasks, like tearing off a piece of tape, and so forth.

But for other tasks, you need
to be able to react really quickly to what's happening.

So for example, the
candy unwrapping-- you need to-- we actually
were able to get a policy

to do the initial step of
picking up the two sides of it and then pulling. But then the next
step involves finding

where the flap is on the candy
and then opening the candy.

And with a small amount of
data around 50 demonstrations, we found that the robot
wasn't able to complete

that next step of finding
the flap and then opening. We think that with
more data, we should

be able to handle that
sort of challenge. But there's also a question of
how much data you might need.

And so we're also trying
to do some research along the lines of pushing
the robot's ability

to react to these certain
scenarios efficiently, and so forth. So yeah, also happy to
answer more questions

on the topic of that project. SPEAKER: What are some of the
most promising approaches you

find very promising
for building actually robots with true
artificial intelligence?

Would you be able
to answer that? CHELSEA FINN: Yeah. I think that the--

I mean, the approaches that
I talked about today I think are some of the most
promising because those are the things that
I'm working on,

and I wouldn't work on them
if I didn't think that they were the most promising. So scaling up data I
think is really important,

allowing robots to-- and just generally, systems for
adapting is really important.

I think that embodiment-- I like studying robots
because they're actually embodied in the real world,
in the world that we live in.

And unlike things
like language models, they have to contend
with a lot of things

that come up in the real world
that are really challenging. Another thing that
I'll mention is

that I've been talking a
lot about scaling data, and I think that we also-- a lot of the data that
I talked about before

was collected by a person
controlling the robot. And I think that
in the long-term, we really need robots that
can collect data autonomously

on their own and operate with
autonomy in the real world.

And that sort of autonomy
is surprisingly hard. We find that agents and robots
will get stuck all the time

and be sure what to do. It's possible that we need
a parent to help the robot,

just analogous to how kids
have parents that are helpful.

But yeah, there's
lots of open problems. And yeah, generally the
things I find most promising are along the lines of
what I presented today.

SPEAKER: And if I
follow up on that, maybe it's the same answer. Which ones are you
the most excited about

or what you actually hope
to see maybe in the next, let's say, 10 or
15 years, something

you're very excited
about hoping to see? CHELSEA FINN: Yeah.

So I think that
everything that-- all the ideas that I presented
are I think are necessary. I think that we need
broad data sets.

We need to adapt at test
time to get robots that can operate in the real world.

So I think that there isn't
any one thing necessarily that I'm most excited about,
because I think that--

I guess, I think that robotics
is a really hard problem, and I'm a little bit more
somewhat pessimistic,

I think, in terms
of actually the kind of timeline for getting robots
out into the real world.

That said, in the
next 5 to 10 years, I'd love to see results
that show that we can start to push robots out of the lab
into unstructured environments,

and so forth, with these kinds
of learning-based approaches, and also start to see pretrained
models start to pop up

that are useful
and can be used off the shelf by lots of people.

SPEAKER: Thank you so
much, and I apologize-- I apologize to put

CHELSEA FINN: Yeah, definitely. I think that my

by getting your feet wet.

I think that my first
experience working-- well, so I did a little bit of
LEGO Robotics in middle school,

I guess. And that was fun and definitely
introduced all the challenges that come up with
building a system

with different components,
with sensors, with actuators. And that was fairly accessible.

And then I also, in college,
took a course on robotics, and it was a lab
course where we built

a robot from scratch, built some
sensors for it, and actually also--

yeah, also had the robot do
various tasks, and so forth.

In our research, we mostly
buy robots off the shelf and really focus on the
brand of the robot, which I think is really the bottleneck.

I don't think that
limited by the hardware. And fortunately, there
are some robot platforms that are fairly--

well, they're getting
more and more inexpensive, so there are various
mobile robot platforms

that have a few wheels. I think Amazon has a platform
called the DeepRacer that's a few hundred dollars, and
there's some other platforms

as well. And yeah, I think
that trying to-- if that's something
that's within reach, then I think that, yeah, trying
to actually just try stuff out

on the robot is a great
place to get started. Of course, another
place to get started is to learn more about
reinforcement learning.

As Petra mentioned,
I'm teaching a course on deep reinforcement
learning in the spring.

And there's also
lots of resources online to explore
these kinds of things.

SPEAKER: Maybe the last question
because I see that questions still keep coming. But at the same time,
we need to actually make

the stop at some point. What would you recommend as

Where to look for-- where to find out what's

any favorite blogs you read, any

CHELSEA FINN:
Yeah, so let's see. So in terms of
tools, one physics

simulator that we use a lot is
the MuJoCo physics simulator, and it's fully open source. And if you want to get
started playing around

with robots and simulation, that
could be a good place to start. I think there's some
starter examples,

and you can try to get
the robot in simulation to do different things.

In terms of resources
for just learning

about high-level ideas of
the field, Pieter Abbeel, who actually was one
of my PhD advisors,

he has a podcast called
The Robot Brains podcast. And that's a great
place to learn about various
experts in the field,

including both academics, as
well as people in industry.  And then, if you really
want to dive deep,

you can look at robot
conferences, like Robotics: Science and Systems
is a conference that we submit to
a lot, and then

also the Conference on Robot
Learning are both great. And oftentimes, they have
actually videos of the talks

at these conferences in addition
to the paper proceedings available online.

And then, yeah, I mean,
there's various course content that I think is great,
and course content is probably

actually, in some ways,
more educational and more

useful than conference
videos, for example, because they're really aimed
at teaching, rather than being

aimed at sharing latest
research results. So it depends on what
you're looking for.
